main event: On 30 April 1948, at Anacostia Naval Air Station, a naval pilot observed a yellow spherical object estimated to be 25-40 feet in diameter flying at about 100 mph at an altitude of 1500 feet.
interesting points: The object was heading in a south to north direction, opposite to the prevailing winds, and followed a constant altitude, which was unusual.
Pilot did not pursue the object further due to it entering prohibited flying areas such as the U.S. Capitol and White House areas.
Project 'SIGN', responsible for investigating unidentified flying objects, analyzed multiple incidents and identified several as having the greatest possibility of being balloons.
The document contains evaluations by Dr. Hynek, categorizing incidents into astronomical, non-astronomical with other explanations, and non-astronomical with no evident explanation.
The report includes a typewritten checklist detailing the observations made by the naval pilot, including details about the speed, altitude, and color of the object.
result: The incident is documented as 'Incident #126' with the conclusion that the observed object appeared to be a balloon, although the constant altitude and unusual flight path raised attention.
sighted object: A yellow spherical object estimated to be 25-40 feet in diameter
witnesses: The observer was a Lt. Commander in the U.S. Navy.
photographs: The report does not contain any photographs.
